trans-unit.source: Create and load data into Hive tables from Blob storage | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Create and load data into Hive tables from Blob storage | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Create Hive tables and load data in blob to hive tables
trans-unit.target: Create Hive tables and load data in blob to hive tables

trans-unit.source: In this document, generic Hive queries that create Hive tables and load data from Azure blob storage are presented.
trans-unit.target: In this document, generic Hive queries that create Hive tables and load data from Azure blob storage are presented.

trans-unit.source: Some guidance is also provided on partitioning Hive tables and on using the Optimized Row Columnar (ORC) formatting to improve query performance.
trans-unit.target: Some guidance is also provided on partitioning Hive tables and on using the Optimized Row Columnar (ORC) formatting to improve query performance.

trans-unit.source: This article assumes that you have:
trans-unit.target: This article assumes that you have:

trans-unit.source: Created an Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: Created an Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: If you need instructions, see <linkText>Create an Azure Storage account</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: If you need instructions, see <linkText>Create an Azure Storage account</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Provisioned a customized Hadoop cluster with the HDInsight service.
trans-unit.target: Provisioned a customized Hadoop cluster with the HDInsight service.

trans-unit.source: If you need instructions, see <linkText>Customize Azure HDInsight Hadoop clusters for advanced analytics</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you need instructions, see <linkText>Customize Azure HDInsight Hadoop clusters for advanced analytics</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Enabled remote access to the cluster, logged in, and opened the Hadoop Command Line console.
trans-unit.target: Enabled remote access to the cluster, logged in, and opened the Hadoop Command Line console.

trans-unit.source: If you need instructions, see <linkText>Access the Head Node of Hadoop Cluster</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you need instructions, see <linkText>Access the Head Node of Hadoop Cluster</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: If you created an Azure virtual machine by following the instructions provided in Set up an Azure virtual machine for advanced analytics, this script file should have been downloaded to the C:\\Users\\\\\Documents\\Data Science Scripts directory on the virtual machine. These Hive queries only require that you plug in your own data schema and Azure blob storage configuration in the appropriate fields to be ready for submission.
trans-unit.target: If you created an Azure virtual machine by following the instructions provided in Set up an Azure virtual machine for advanced analytics, this script file should have been downloaded to the C:\\Users\\\\\Documents\\Data Science Scripts directory on the virtual machine. These Hive queries only require that you plug in your own data schema and Azure blob storage configuration in the appropriate fields to be ready for submission.

trans-unit.source: We assume that the data for Hive tables is in an uncompressed tabular format, and that the data has been uploaded to the default (or to an additional) container of the storage account used by the Hadoop cluster.
trans-unit.target: We assume that the data for Hive tables is in an uncompressed tabular format, and that the data has been uploaded to the default (or to an additional) container of the storage account used by the Hadoop cluster.

trans-unit.source: If you want to practice on the NYC Taxi Trip Data, you need to first download the 24 NYC Taxi Trip Data files (12 Trip files, and 12 Fare files), unzip all files into .csv files, and then upload them to the default (or appropriate container) of the Azure storage account that was created by the procedure outlined in the Customize Azure HDInsight Hadoop clusters for Advanced Analytics Process and Technology topic.
trans-unit.target: If you want to practice on the NYC Taxi Trip Data, you need to first download the 24 NYC Taxi Trip Data files (12 Trip files, and 12 Fare files), unzip all files into .csv files, and then upload them to the default (or appropriate container) of the Azure storage account that was created by the procedure outlined in the Customize Azure HDInsight Hadoop clusters for Advanced Analytics Process and Technology topic.

trans-unit.source: The process to upload the .csv files to the default container on the storage account can be found on this <linkText>page</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The process to upload the .csv files to the default container on the storage account can be found on this <linkText>page</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Hive queries can be submitted from the Hadoop Command Line console on the head node of the Hadoop cluster.
trans-unit.target: Hive queries can be submitted from the Hadoop Command Line console on the head node of the Hadoop cluster.

trans-unit.source: To do this, log into the head node of the Hadoop cluster, open the Hadoop Command Line console, and submit the Hive queries from there.
trans-unit.target: To do this, log into the head node of the Hadoop cluster, open the Hadoop Command Line console, and submit the Hive queries from there.

trans-unit.source: For instructions on how to do this, see <linkText>Submit Hive Queries to HDInsight Hadoop clusters in the advanced analytics process</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For instructions on how to do this, see <linkText>Submit Hive Queries to HDInsight Hadoop clusters in the advanced analytics process</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Users can also use the Query Console (Hive Editor) by entering the URL
trans-unit.target: Users can also use the Query Console (Hive Editor) by entering the URL

trans-unit.source: https://<Hadoop cluster name>.azurehdinsight.net/Home/HiveEditor
trans-unit.target: https://<Hadoop cluster name>.azurehdinsight.net/Home/HiveEditor

trans-unit.source: into a web browser.
trans-unit.target: into a web browser.

trans-unit.source: Note that you will be prompted to input the Hadoop cluster credentials to log in, so you should have these credentials handy.
trans-unit.target: Note that you will be prompted to input the Hadoop cluster credentials to log in, so you should have these credentials handy.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can <linkText>Submit Hive jobs using PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can <linkText>Submit Hive jobs using PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The Hive queries are shared in the [Github repository](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/tree/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts/samplehivecreatedbtblsloaddata_generic.hql) and can be downloaded from there.
trans-unit.target: The Hive queries are shared in the [Github repository](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/tree/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts/samplehivecreatedbtblsloaddata_generic.hql) and can be downloaded from there.

trans-unit.source: Here is the Hive query that creates a Hive table.
trans-unit.target: Here is the Hive query that creates a Hive table.

trans-unit.source: Here are the descriptions of the fields that users need to plug in and other configurations:
trans-unit.target: Here are the descriptions of the fields that users need to plug in and other configurations:

trans-unit.source: <database name>: the name of the database users want to create.
trans-unit.target: <database name>: the name of the database users want to create.

trans-unit.source: If users just want to use the default database, the query create database... can be omitted.
trans-unit.target: If users just want to use the default database, the query create database... can be omitted.

trans-unit.source: <table name>: the name of the table users want to create within the specified database.
trans-unit.target: <table name>: the name of the table users want to create within the specified database.

trans-unit.source: If users want to use the default database, the table can be directly referred by <table name> without <database name>.
trans-unit.target: If users want to use the default database, the table can be directly referred by <table name> without <database name>.

trans-unit.source: <field separator>: the separator that delimits fields in the data file to be uploaded to the Hive table.
trans-unit.target: <field separator>: the separator that delimits fields in the data file to be uploaded to the Hive table.

trans-unit.source: <line separator>: the separator that delimits lines in the data file.
trans-unit.target: <line separator>: the separator that delimits lines in the data file.

trans-unit.source: <storage location>: the Azure storage location to save the data of Hive tables.
trans-unit.target: <storage location>: the Azure storage location to save the data of Hive tables.

trans-unit.source: If users do not specify LOCATION <storage location>, the database and the tables are stored in hive/warehouse/ directory in the default container of the Hive cluster by default.
trans-unit.target: If users do not specify LOCATION <storage location>, the database and the tables are stored in hive/warehouse/ directory in the default container of the Hive cluster by default.

trans-unit.source: If a user wants to specify the storage location, the storage location has to be within the default container for the database and tables.
trans-unit.target: If a user wants to specify the storage location, the storage location has to be within the default container for the database and tables.

trans-unit.source: This location has to be referred as location relative to the default container of the cluster in the format of 'wasb:///<directory 1>/' or 'wasb:///<directory 1>/<directory 2>/', etc. After the query is executed, the relative directories will be created within the default container.
trans-unit.target: This location has to be referred as location relative to the default container of the cluster in the format of 'wasb:///<directory 1>/' or 'wasb:///<directory 1>/<directory 2>/', etc. After the query is executed, the relative directories will be created within the default container.

trans-unit.source: TBLPROPERTIES("skip.header.line.count"="1"): If the data file has a header line, users have to add this property at the end of the create table query.
trans-unit.target: TBLPROPERTIES("skip.header.line.count"="1"): If the data file has a header line, users have to add this property at the end of the create table query.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, the header line will be loaded as a record to the table.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, the header line will be loaded as a record to the table.

trans-unit.source: If the data file does not have a header line, this configuration can be omitted in the query.
trans-unit.target: If the data file does not have a header line, this configuration can be omitted in the query.

trans-unit.source: Here is the Hive query that loads data into a Hive table.
trans-unit.target: Here is the Hive query that loads data into a Hive table.

trans-unit.source: <path to blob data>: If the blob file to be uploaded to the Hive table is in the default container of the HDInsight Hadoop cluster, the <path to blob data> should be in the format 'wasb:///<directory in this container>/<blob file name>'.
trans-unit.target: <path to blob data>: If the blob file to be uploaded to the Hive table is in the default container of the HDInsight Hadoop cluster, the <path to blob data> should be in the format 'wasb:///<directory in this container>/<blob file name>'.

trans-unit.source: The blob file can also be in an additional container of the HDInsight Hadoop cluster.
trans-unit.target: The blob file can also be in an additional container of the HDInsight Hadoop cluster.

trans-unit.source: In this case, <path to blob data> should be in the format 'wasb://<container name>@<storage account name>.blob.core.windows.net/<blob file name>'.
trans-unit.target: In this case, <path to blob data> should be in the format 'wasb://<container name>@<storage account name>.blob.core.windows.net/<blob file name>'.

trans-unit.source: The blob data to be uploaded to Hive table has to be in the default or additional container of the storage account for the Hadoop cluster.
trans-unit.target: The blob data to be uploaded to Hive table has to be in the default or additional container of the storage account for the Hadoop cluster.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, the LOAD DATA query will fail complaining that it cannot access the data.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, the LOAD DATA query will fail complaining that it cannot access the data.

trans-unit.source: If the data is large, partitioning the table is beneficial for queries that only need to scan a few partitions of the table.
trans-unit.target: If the data is large, partitioning the table is beneficial for queries that only need to scan a few partitions of the table.

trans-unit.source: For instance, it is reasonable to partition the log data of a web site by dates.
trans-unit.target: For instance, it is reasonable to partition the log data of a web site by dates.

trans-unit.source: In addition to partitioning Hive tables, it is also beneficial to store the Hive data in the Optimized Row Columnar (ORC) format.
trans-unit.target: In addition to partitioning Hive tables, it is also beneficial to store the Hive data in the Optimized Row Columnar (ORC) format.

trans-unit.source: For more information on ORC formatting, see Using ORC files improves performance when Hive is reading, writing, and processing data.
trans-unit.target: For more information on ORC formatting, see Using ORC files improves performance when Hive is reading, writing, and processing data.

trans-unit.source: Here is the Hive query that creates a partitioned table and loads data into it.
trans-unit.target: Here is the Hive query that creates a partitioned table and loads data into it.

trans-unit.source: When querying partitioned tables, it is recommended to add the partition condition in the beginning of the where clause as this improves the efficacy of searching significantly.
trans-unit.target: When querying partitioned tables, it is recommended to add the partition condition in the beginning of the where clause as this improves the efficacy of searching significantly.

trans-unit.source: Users cannot directly load data from blob storage into Hive tables that is stored in the ORC format.
trans-unit.target: Users cannot directly load data from blob storage into Hive tables that is stored in the ORC format.

trans-unit.source: Here are the steps that the users need to take in order to load data from Azure blobs to Hive tables stored in ORC format.
trans-unit.target: Here are the steps that the users need to take in order to load data from Azure blobs to Hive tables stored in ORC format.

trans-unit.source: Create an external table STORED AS TEXTFILE and load data from blob storage to the table.
trans-unit.target: Create an external table STORED AS TEXTFILE and load data from blob storage to the table.

trans-unit.source: Create an internal table with the same schema as the external table in step 1, with the same field delimiter, and store the Hive data in the ORC format.
trans-unit.target: Create an internal table with the same schema as the external table in step 1, with the same field delimiter, and store the Hive data in the ORC format.

trans-unit.source: Select data from the external table in step 1 and insert into the ORC table
trans-unit.target: Select data from the external table in step 1 and insert into the ORC table

trans-unit.source: If the TEXTFILE table <database name>.<external textfile table name> has partitions, in STEP 3, the SELECT * FROM . command will select the partition variable as a field in the returned data set. Inserting it into the <database name>.<ORC table name> will fail since <database name>.<ORC table name> does not have the partition variable as a field in the table schema. In this case, users need to specifically select the fields to be inserted to <database name>.<ORC table name> as follows:
trans-unit.target: If the TEXTFILE table <database name>.<external textfile table name> has partitions, in STEP 3, the SELECT * FROM . command will select the partition variable as a field in the returned data set. Inserting it into the <database name>.<ORC table name> will fail since <database name>.<ORC table name> does not have the partition variable as a field in the table schema. In this case, users need to specifically select the fields to be inserted to <database name>.<ORC table name> as follows:

trans-unit.source: It is safe to drop the <external textfile table name> when using the following query after all data has been inserted into <database name>.<ORC table name>:
trans-unit.target: It is safe to drop the <external textfile table name> when using the following query after all data has been inserted into <database name>.<ORC table name>:

trans-unit.source: After following this procedure, you should have a table with data in the ORC format ready to use.
trans-unit.target: After following this procedure, you should have a table with data in the ORC format ready to use.
